title: Diary of an Overland Journey from Bombay to England, and of a year's residence in Great Britain
author: Khurshed-ji, ARDSHER
snippet: (41.)—Edinburgh or Mid Lothian, a county of Scotland, about thirty miles long, and in breadth from sixteen to twenty: its superficial extent is 360 square miles, or 230,400 English acres; it is bounded north by the Firth of Forth, and the Almond which separates it from West Lothian or Linlithgowshire, east by the county of Haddington, south by the counties of Lanark, Peebles and Berwick, and on the west corner by part ofthe County of Linlithgow; the general aspect is pleasant; about one third consists of arable land, fertile, and highly cultivated, and affords excellent crops; the Moorfoot and the Pentland Hills pass through the county, the highest point of which rises 1700 feet above the level of the sea. This county abounds in most parts with Coal, Limestone, Freestone, and Iron ore of different species : the principal rivers ofthe county are the north and south Esk, the Almond and the water of Leith : besides Edinburgh the metropolis of the county, and Leith, the county contains the towns and villages of Dalkeith, Musselburg, Porto Bello, Lasswade, Pennycuich, Midcalder, Gilmerton, and New Haven, where

title: The Black Douglas ... Second impression.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: And ever as he gazed at her the Earl of Douglas grew more and more in love with the Lady Sybilla. There was no covert side through which a burn plunged downward from the steep side of Moorfoot, but they wandered it alone together. Early and late they might have been met, he with his face turned upon her, and she looking straight forward with the same inscrutable calm.

title: The Black Douglas ... Second impression.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: It was in the gracious fulness of the early autumn, when the sheaves were set up in many a park and little warded holt about the Moorfoot braes, that William Douglas and SybUla de Thouars stood together upon a crest of hill, crowned with dwarf birch and thick foliaged alder — a place in the retirement of whose sylvan bower they had already spent many tranced hours.

title: Autobiography of Samuel Smiles ...
author: Smiles, Samuel
snippet: To the west, lies the richly wooded fertile valley, over the woods of Saltoun, once the seat of The Patriot, Andrew Fletcher, towards Moorfoot and Soutra Hill. Looking due south, the eye stretches over the plantations surrounding the ancient fortalice of Lethington, once the residence of Chancellor Maitland (the astute secretary and adviser of Mary, Queen of Scots), where the "Political's Walk" is still to be seen.
